data.template: 2   These people had a little window at the back of their house from which a splendid garden could be seen, which was full of the most beautiful flowers and herbs.

>It was, however, surrounded by a high wall, and no one dared to go into it because it belonged to an enchantress who had great power and was dreaded by all the world. One day the woman was standing by this window and looking down into the garden when she saw a bed which was planted with the most beautiful rampion (rapunzel), and it looked so fresh and green that she longed for it, she quite pined away, and began to look pale and miserable. Then her husband was alarmed, and asked:

>At twilight, he clambered down over the wall into the garden of the enchantress, hastily clutched a handful of rampion, and took it to his wife. She at once made herself a salad of it and ate it greedily. It tasted so good to her—so very good—that the next day she longed for it three times as much as before. If he was to have any rest, her husband must once more descend into the garden. In the gloom of evening therefore, he let himself down again; but when he had clambered down the wall, he was terribly afraid, for he saw the enchantress standing before him.
>Then the enchantress allowed her anger to be softened, and said to him:

The man, in his terror, consented to everything, and when the woman was brought to bed, the enchantress appeared at once, gave the child the name of Rapunzel, and took it away with her.

n

Which detail best supports the meaning of impressed in paragraph 8?
data.template: 8    After the two had planned together, they <strong><span class=
>called a meeting of the thrushes. The plan was really Peter's, but Solomon did most of the talking.
>He began by saying that he had been impressed by the thrushes'
>put them into a good mood, as it was meant to do. Other birds, said Solomon, didn't line their nests with mud, so they could not hold water.

metadata.distractor_rationale:
Distractor Rationales:

nn

called...: Incorrect. This detail does not show that Solomon has a strong positive feeling about the work the thrushes have done.

nn

He began...: Incorrect. This detail does not show that Solomon has a strong positive feeling about the work the thrushes have done. 

nn

excellence...: Correct.

nn

put them...: Incorrect. This detail does not show that Solomon has a strong positive feeling about the work the thrushes have done.

n

data.stimulus: Which two details best support the meaning of depressed in paragraph 6?
data.template: >They were too honest to demand it back, but he saw that they were upset. They
>cast such black looks at Solomon that he flew away to the end of the island.
>He sat there very depressed with his
>head buried in his wings. Now Peter knew that
>unless Solomon was on your side, you never got anything done for you on the island. So he followed him and tried to

metadata.distractor_rationale:
Distractor Rationales:

nn

They were...: Incorrect. This detail does not show that depressed means that someone is in very low spirits.

nn

cast such...: Incorrect. This detail shows why Solomon was depressed but does not explain what depressed means.

nn

He sat...: Incorrect. Someone can be sitting for reasons other than being sad, so this detail by itself is not enough to show the meaning of depressed.

nn

head buried...: Correct.

nn

unless Solomon...: Incorrect. This shows how others feel about Solomon, not how he was feeling in relation to being depressed.

nn

make him...: Correct.

n

data.template: >You remember a good deal about them in your babyhood. It is a great pity you can't write, for soon you forget. I have heard of children who declared that they had never once seen a fairy. Very likely
>if they said this in the Kensington Gardens, they were standing looking at a fairy all the time.
>The reason they didn't see her was that she pretended to be something else. This is one of their best tricks.
>They usually pretend to be flowers. They dress exactly like flowers and change with the seasons, putting on white when lilies are in and blue for bluebells, and so on. . . .

metadata.distractor_rationale:
Distractor Rationales:

nn

Part B:

nn

You remember...: Incorrect. This detail seems to support an incorrect answer in Part A.

nn

if they...: Correct.

nn

the reason...: Incorrect. This detail seems to support an incorrect answer in Part A.

nn

They usually...: Incorrect. This detail seems to support an incorrect answer in Part A.

n

Choose the two details that best help show how the events in paragraph 3 build on what happens in paragraph 2.
data.template: 3  When they think you are not looking they lively skip along. If you look, however, and there is no time to hide, <span class=
>they stand quite still pretending to be flowers. Then, after you have passed without knowing that they were fairies,

>they rush home and tell their mothers they have had such an adventure. The Fairy Basin in Kensington Gardens is all covered with ground-ivy, with flowers growing in it here and there. Most of them really are flowers, but
>some of them are fairies. You never can be sure of them, but a good plan is to walk by looking the other way, and then turn around sharply.
>Another good plan is to stare them down. After a long time
>they can't help winking, and then you know for certain that they are fairies. . . .

metadata.distractor_rationale:
Distractor Rationales:

nn

they stand...: Correct.

nn

They rush...: Incorrect. While plausible, this detail does not show how paragraph 3 builds on what happens in paragraph 2, which is that the fairies pretend to be flowers.

nn

some of them...: Correct.

nn

Another good...: Incorrect. While plausible, this detail does not show how paragraph 3 builds on what happens in paragraph 2, which is that the fairies pretend to be flowers.

nn

they can't...: Incorrect. While plausible, this detail does not show how paragraph 3 builds on what happens in paragraph 2, which is that the fairies pretend to be flowers.

n

data.stimulus: Which two details best support the meaning of dwellings as it is used in paragraph 4?
data.template: >it is no use looking for them because
>they are the exact opposite of our houses. You can see our houses by day but you can't see them by dark. Well, you can see their houses by dark, but you can't see them by day,

>for they are the color of night. I never heard of anyone yet who could see night in the daytime. This does not mean that they are black, for night has its colors just as day has, but ever so much brighter. Their blues and reds and greens are like ours with a light behind them.

>The palace is entirely built of many-colored glasses. It is the loveliest of all royal dwellings. The queen sometimes complains because the common people will peep in to see what she is doing. They are very curious folk, and

metadata.distractor_rationale:
Distractor Rationales:

nn

It is no use..: Incorrect. This detail does not support that the dwellings are houses and palaces.

nn

they are the exact...: Correct.

nn

for they are: Incorrect. This detail references how their dwellings are colored but does not support the meaning of the given word. 

nn

The palace...: Correct.

nn

press quite...: Incorrect. This detail references glass windows that are in the palace but does not support the meaning of the given word.

n

data.template: 10 So this was the truth about mothers.

>The toads!

nn

11 Still it is best to be careful.
>No one knows so quickly as a child when he should give in.
asked the lost boys, confused. They knew in what they called their hearts that

>one can get on quite well without a mother, and that it is only the mothers who think you can't.

nn

14
Wendy replied firmly, for the horrible thought had come to her:

metadata.distractor_rationale:
Distractor Rationales:

nn

The toads!: Incorrect. In paragraph 6, Peter explains his belief that his mother replaced him with another child, which prompts Wendy and her brothers to want to go home; this detail shows how the Lost Boys feel about mothers, not how Wendy and her brothers react.

nn

No one...: Incorrect. While plausible, this detail does not show how paragraphs 10–14 build on what happens in paragraph 6.

nn

Wendy, let...: Correct.

nn

Not to-night...: Incorrect. The boys are confused by Wendy's reactions, not reacting to what Peter shared in paragraph 6.

nn

One can...: Incorrect. While plausible, this detail does not show how paragraphs 10–14 build on what happens in paragraph 6.

nn

At once...: Correct.

n

nn

he replied...: Incorrect. Peter's cool response does not show that Wendy is fearful.

data.stimulus: Which two details best support the meaning of dignity as it is used in paragraph 26?
data.template: >Tootles responded. For that one moment he

>dropped his silliness and spoke with dignity.

nn

27

>drew back his hanger and shook it at the other boys. The others held back uneasily. Then Peter returned, and they saw at once that they would get no support from him. He would keep no girl in the Neverland against her will.

n

metadata.distractor_rationale:
Distractor Rationales:

nn

Tootles...: Incorrect. This simply says that Tootles responds but does not describe how, which would be necessary to support the meaning of dignity.

nn

dropped...: Correct.

nn

Nobody...: Incorrect. While this detail seems like Tootles is being humble, it references that he is often known as the silly one that no one listens to.

nn

like...: Correct.

nn

drew...: Incorrect. This detail is part of him threatening the boys, which does not how he acted with dignity.

n
